A cow is a bovine that is kept as livestock. Cattle are commonly raised as livestock for meat (beef or veal), as dairy animals for milk and other dairy products, and as draft animals (oxen or bullocks) (pulling carts, plows and the like).

A cow is a female that has had at least one calf. Young cows are called heifers. After about two years, the heifer has her first calf. After that, she is called a cow.
Holstein cows are black and white cows that are the most common dairy cows in the world.

Cattle—colloquially cows—are the most common type of large domesticated ungulates. They are a prominent modern member of the subfamily Bovinae, are the most widespread species of the genus Bos, and are most commonly classified collectively as Bos taurus.

The cow is a domesticated form of the wild ox.

Holstein Friesian cattle are a breed of dairy cattle originating from the Dutch provinces of North Holland and Friesland, and Schleswig-Holstein in Northern Germany.
The Holstein Friesian is a breed of dairy cattle originating from the Dutch provinces of North Holland and Friesland, and Schleswig-Holstein in Northern Germany and Jutland.
The species Bos taurus is believed to have originated in the Near East and then spread through the world.
